analyzeResult.content:
PHILIP MORRIS U. S. A.
INTER - OFFICE CORRESPONDENCE Richmond, Virginia
To:
Date: 2/7/91
From: D.S. Kellogg
Subject: 8 weekly summary
One area relating to project I and one to B were the focus of the previous week. The Fe-oxide sol-gel provided by D. Schleich was finally relocated this week. The effect on CO evolution of dipping 209 heat sources in this sol gel were examined. The results are attached. The set of instructions was not located until yesterday, so instead of soaking for 30 min and drying at 150 C, I soaked several PM209 heat sources in the sol-gel solution overnight, and first dried them in a vacuum oven at ca. 95 C, then redried the remaining ones at 200 C overnight in the vacuum oven. Contrary to the report by Schleich, no degradation of the heat source was observed. The heat sources weight increased from an average of 115 mg to ca. 150 mg after soaking in the sol-gel and subsequent drying at 200 C. The CO and CO, produced by these heat sources are tabulated below.
Pretreatment
co, µg/mg
CO24 Hg/mg
none:
217
3408
95 ℃ bake
102
2414
200 ℃ bake
102
2068
CO evolution appears to have been reduced by ca. 50% by sol-gel treatment. This is still significantly higher than nitride-based heat sources. In addition to CO and CO, evolution, sol-gel treated heat sources also evolved ethylene glycol and formaldehyde, a decomposition product of ethylene glycol. EGAMS plots are attached. Baking at 200 C overnight significantly reduced ethylene glycol evolution during burning, but did not eliminate it entirely. Also not the small oxygen consumption peak not accompanied by CO or CO, evolution at higher temperatures. This consumption might be due to Fe" oxidation. The heat sources were also burned on the end of a thermocouple to determine if sol-gel treatment had any effect on free-burn. The results are attached .. No significant differences were observed, except that the treated heat sources were somewhat harder to light with a butane lighter than the untreated heat source, and the heat source dried at ca. 100 C reached a lower maximum temperature than the other two.
With Rose Arthur's help, 1.2 Q Au heaters deposited on sol-gel paper were fired with different voltages to assess their behavior under a load. A photocopy of the fired heaters is attached. A range of voltages from 3.5 to 4.6 was applied to four different strip heaters. Lower voltages actually results in greater charring of the paper. When higher voltages were applied, the contacts arced and burned at one of the clip leads (always the same one), causing a break in the circuit. This phenomena did not happen to as great an extent with lower voltages and the heater actually lasted the entire length of the pulse. The results are tabulated below.
2020238843
Lenpt
le:7-8.3 V

Subject: 8 weekly summary
One area relating to project I and one to B were the focus of the previous
week. The Fe-oxide sol-gel provided by D. Schleich was finally relocated
this week. The effect on CO evolution of dipping 209 heat sources in this
sol gel were examined. The results are attached. The set of instructions
was not located until yesterday, so instead of soaking for 30 min and drying
at 150 C, I soaked several PM209 heat sources in the sol-gel solution
overnight, and first dried them in a vacuum oven at ca. 95 C, then redried
the remaining ones at 200 C overnight in the vacuum oven. Contrary to the
report by Schleich, no degradation of the heat source was observed. The heat
sources weight increased from an average of 115 mg to ca. 150 mg after
soaking in the sol-gel and subsequent drying at 200 C. The CO and CO,
produced by these heat sources are tabulated below.

CO evolution appears to have been reduced by ca. 50% by sol-gel treatment.
This is still significantly higher than nitride-based heat sources. In
addition to CO and CO, evolution, sol-gel treated heat sources also evolved
ethylene glycol and formaldehyde, a decomposition product of ethylene glycol.
EGAMS plots are attached. Baking at 200 C overnight significantly reduced
ethylene glycol evolution during burning, but did not eliminate it entirely.
Also not the small oxygen consumption peak not accompanied by CO or CO,
evolution at higher temperatures. This consumption might be due to Fe"
oxidation. The heat sources were also burned on the end of a thermocouple to
determine if sol-gel treatment had any effect on free-burn. The results are
attached .. No significant differences were observed, except that the treated
heat sources were somewhat harder to light with a butane lighter than the
untreated heat source, and the heat source dried at ca. 100 C reached a
lower maximum temperature than the other two.
With Rose Arthur's help, 1.2 Q Au heaters deposited on sol-gel paper were
fired with different voltages to assess their behavior under a load. A
photocopy of the fired heaters is attached. A range of voltages from 3.5 to
4.6 was applied to four different strip heaters. Lower voltages actually
results in greater charring of the paper. When higher voltages were applied,
the contacts arced and burned at one of the clip leads (always the same one),
causing a break in the circuit. This phenomena did not happen to as great an
extent with lower voltages and the heater actually lasted the entire length
of the pulse. The results are tabulated below.

paragraphs.content: One area relating to project I and one to B were the focus of the previous week. The Fe-oxide sol-gel provided by D. Schleich was finally relocated this week. The effect on CO evolution of dipping 209 heat sources in this sol gel were examined. The results are attached. The set of instructions was not located until yesterday, so instead of soaking for 30 min and drying at 150 C, I soaked several PM209 heat sources in the sol-gel solution overnight, and first dried them in a vacuum oven at ca. 95 C, then redried the remaining ones at 200 C overnight in the vacuum oven. Contrary to the report by Schleich, no degradation of the heat source was observed. The heat sources weight increased from an average of 115 mg to ca. 150 mg after soaking in the sol-gel and subsequent drying at 200 C. The CO and CO, produced by these heat sources are tabulated below.

CO evolution appears to have been reduced by ca. 50% by sol-gel treatment. This is still significantly higher than nitride-based heat sources. In addition to CO and CO, evolution, sol-gel treated heat sources also evolved ethylene glycol and formaldehyde, a decomposition product of ethylene glycol. EGAMS plots are attached. Baking at 200 C overnight significantly reduced ethylene glycol evolution during burning, but did not eliminate it entirely. Also not the small oxygen consumption peak not accompanied by CO or CO, evolution at higher temperatures. This consumption might be due to Fe" oxidation. The heat sources were also burned on the end of a thermocouple to determine if sol-gel treatment had any effect on free-burn. The results are attached .. No significant differences were observed, except that the treated heat sources were somewhat harder to light with a butane lighter than the untreated heat source, and the heat source dried at ca. 100 C reached a lower maximum temperature than the other two.

With Rose Arthur's help, 1.2 Q Au heaters deposited on sol-gel paper were fired with different voltages to assess their behavior under a load. A photocopy of the fired heaters is attached. A range of voltages from 3.5 to 4.6 was applied to four different strip heaters. Lower voltages actually results in greater charring of the paper. When higher voltages were applied, the contacts arced and burned at one of the clip leads (always the same one), causing a break in the circuit. This phenomena did not happen to as great an extent with lower voltages and the heater actually lasted the entire length of the pulse. The results are tabulated below.
